title: Disability coverage for some patients will see automatic insurance change
text:
Changes in Idaho ‘s Dual Medicare-Medicaid insurance Coverage Thousands of Idahoans who rely on both Medicare and Medicaid for healthcare will see changes to their coverage starting in June. The Idaho department of Health and Welfare (IDHW) recently announced the transition from Blue Cross of Idaho to UnitedHealthcare as the contracted provider for dual-enrollment recipients.
What are Dual-Enrollment Plans? Dual-enrollment plans provide coverage for individuals who are eligible for both Medicare and Medicaid. This is a crucial safety net for manny, particularly those with low incomes and complex health needs. Medicaid often covers services not included in Medicare, such as long-term care, in-home support, and certain prescription drugs.
Timeline of Changes Here’s a breakdown of the key dates and actions for enrollees:
June 1, 2025: United Healthcare will begin offering its IMPlus dual-enrollment plan in 34 Idaho counties. June 1, 2025 – December 31, 2025: Molina healthcare will be the onyl health plan offering a Medicare-Medicaid Coordinated Plan (MMCP) in these counties. January 1, 2026: Coverage for United’s MMCP will be available statewide. Impact on Enrollees Dual-enrollees currently enrolled with Blue Cross of Idaho in the designated counties will be automatically transitioned to UnitedHealthcare’s IMPlus plan unless they actively choose Molina healthcare’s MMCP.Enrollees in the remaining 10 counties, were fee-for-service Medicaid is used, will not be directly affected.
Resources and Information The IDHW has issued a comprehensive letter to stakeholders, providers, and enrollees outlining these changes in detail. Additionally, they have established a dedicated website with frequently asked questions. More detailed information will be mailed to enrollees in March.
Preparing for the Change IDHW recommends that dual-enrollees review their current coverage, consider their healthcare needs, and compare the offerings of both UnitedHealthcare and Molina Healthcare.
Experts emphasize the importance of understanding the new plan benefits, networks, and any changes to prescription coverage. Don’t hesitate to contact the IDHW or the insurance providers directly with any questions or concerns.
This transition represents a significant change in Idaho’s healthcare landscape.By staying informed, understanding their options, and taking proactive steps, dual-enrollees can ensure a smooth transition and continued access to the vital healthcare services they need.

Transitions in Idaho’s Dual Medicare-Medicaid Insurance Coverage: An Interview with Jill Martin, IDHW Spokesperson What are Dual-Eligible Individuals and Why are These Changes Important, Jill? Jill: Dual-eligible individuals are those who qualify for both Medicare and Medicaid. These changes are important as they affect a vulnerable population with complex healthcare needs, ensuring they have access to the right services and support.
Could You Walk Us Through the Timeline of These Changes? Jill: Certainly.UnitedHealthcare’s IMPlus plan will become available in 34 counties starting June 1, 2025.Until the end of the year, Molina Healthcare will be the only plan offering a Medicare-Medicaid Coordinated Plan (MMCP) in these counties. By January 1, 2026, UnitedHealthcare’s MMCP will be available statewide.
How Will These Changes Impact Current Enrollees in Idaho? Jill: Enrollees in the affected counties with Blue Cross of Idaho will be automatically transitioned to UnitedHealthcare’s IMPlus plan unless they actively choose Molina Healthcare’s MMCP. Those in the remaining counties using fee-for-service Medicaid won’t be directly affected.
What Resources Are Available for Enrollees to Understand These Changes? Jill: IDHW has sent detailed letters to enrollees and providers, created a dedicated FAQ website, and will mail more information to enrollees in March. We encourage everyone to review their current coverage and contact IDHW or the insurance providers directly with any questions.
What Advice Do You Have for Dual-Eligible Idahoans About to Make this Transition? Jill: It’s crucial for dual-enrollees to review their current coverage, understand the new plan benefits, networks, and prescription coverage changes. we want to ensure a smooth transition and continued access to vital healthcare services.
